reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s “eutopia is fragile / narrow target” premise (Sections 2.3–2.4), which is moderately central to the paper’s overall case that mostly-great futures are rare. However, the paper repeatedly conditions on a distribution where there is no serious, coordinated optimization toward the very best outcomes (and explicitly flags ‘navigation/institutions’ as a separate factor deferred to the next essay). Given that framing, pointing out that future societies might build robust error-correcting institutions mainly shifts to a different conditional case than the one being analyzed, so it only weakly undermines the argument as presented. The critique is broadly plausible (institutions can reduce fragility), but it’s underspecified (what mechanisms, why they’d work across moral disagreements, why they’d be robust to lock-in/power capture, etc.), so it provides limited refutational force. It’s clear and focused, with minimal dead weight.
title: Error-correcting institutions may neutralize the fragility of moral progress
